title: How to Make Peach Ice Cream

steps.headline: Heat the half-and-half, sugar, and salt over medium heat until it reaches 175°F (80°C).
steps.description: Pour the half-and-half into a saucepan, then stir in the sugar and the salt. Heat the mixture over medium heat until the sugar dissolves completely, and the temperature reaches 175°F (80°C). Use a candy thermometer to gauge the temperature.

steps.headline: Pour ½ cup (120 milliliters) of the half-and-half mixture into the beaten eggs, and stir.
steps.description: If you have not already done so, crack open and separate the eggs, then beat the yolks with a whisk until they turn light and creamy. Slowly pour ½ cup (120 milliliters) of the half-and-half mixture until the beaten eggs while whisking. This is known as "tempering" the eggs, and prevents them from scrambling. Discard the egg whites, or save them for another recipe.

steps.headline: Pour the egg mixture back into the saucepan.
steps.description: Be sure to pour the egg mixture slowly, and to whisk the half-and-half mixture as you pour. This will prevent the eggs from cooking too fast and scrambling.

steps.headline: Cook the custard over low heat until it thickens.
steps.description: This will take about 5 minutes. The custard is ready when it has become thick enough to coat the back of a metal spoon and reaches 160°F (72°C).

steps.headline: Pour the custard through a strainer into a bowl, and cool it in an ice bath.
steps.description: Fill a sink with ice, then place a bowl inside of it. Set a fine, mesh strainer on top of the bowl, then pour the custard through it. Discard anything caught in the strainer, then stir the custard as it cools. The ice should be level with the custard in the bowl. Do not let any ice get inside of the custard. Make sure that the bowl is large enough to hold the heavy whipping cream as well. You will be mixing everything in this bowl once the mixture cools.

steps.headline: Stir in the heavy whipping cream and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Once the custard has cooled, take the bowl out of the ice bath, and stir in the heavy whipping cream and vanilla extract. You can do this using a whisk or rubber spatula.

steps.headline: Cover the custard with plastic wrap, and refrigerate it for a few hours.
steps.description: It would be better if you chilled it overnight, however. Be sure to press the plastic wrap right against the surface of the custard. This will prevent a skin from forming on top.

steps.headline: Purée the peaches in a blender or food processor.
steps.description: Peel and slice the peaches first, then put them into a blender or food processor. Purée them until you get the consistency you want. The longer you purée them for, the smoother your ice cream will be. If you can't get any fresh peaches, you can use 4 cups (900 grams) of frozen, unsweetened peach slices instead. Let the peaches thaw first; this will make it easier to mix them into the custard.

steps.headline: Stir the peach purée into the custard.
steps.description: You can do this using a rubber spatula or a whisk. Keep stirring until the color is even, and there are no streaks or swirls.

steps.headline: Freeze the ice cream mixture.
steps.description: Fill your ice cream maker two-thirds of the way with the mixture, then freeze the ice cream according to manufacturer's directions. Keep the rest of the mixture in the fridge while you are freezing your current batch. As you finish freezing each batch, put it into a freezer-safe container, and store it in the fridge. If you don't have an ice cream maker, pour the ice cream mixture into a shallow cake or loaf pan, and freeze it for 45 minutes. Stir the ice cream well, making sure to break up any ice crystals. After that, freeze the ice cream for 2 to 4 hours, stirring it every 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Transfer the ice cream into a freezer-safe container, then let it ripen for 2 to 4 hours in the freezer, if desired.
steps.description: Once the ice cream comes out of the ice cream maker, it is ready to serve as a soft-serve type of ice cream. If you want the ice cream to be more firm, you will need to leave it in the freezer for 2 to 4 hours. Even if you are not using an ice cream maker, you might want to do this as well. Keep your ice cream covered as it freezes to prevent ice crystals from forming.

steps.headline: Beat the heavy whipping cream until stiff peaks form.
steps.description: You can do this in an electric stand mixer, a food processor fitted with whisks, or in a bowl with a handheld beater. You want it to feel like whipped cream.

steps.headline: Fold in the sweetened condensed milk with a rubber spatula.
steps.description: Pour the condensed milk into the whipped cream slowly while gently folding it with a rubber spatula. You want the color to be even, with no streaks or swirls.

steps.headline: Peel, slice, and purée the peaches in a blender or food processor.
steps.description: The longer you purée the peaches, the smoother your ice cream will be. Remember, you can always leave some peach chunks for more texture.

steps.headline: Fold the peach purée into the cream mixture.
steps.description: Keep folding the peach purée until the color is even, and no streaks or swirls remain. For a more complex flavor, stir in 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into a loaf pan.
steps.description: The larger the pan, the faster your ice cream will freeze. You can always scoop it into a different container later.

steps.headline: Cover the mixture with plastic wrap, then freeze it for 6 to 8 hours.
steps.description: The longer you freeze the ice cream for, the harder it will become. If you want more of soft-serve type of ice cream, then you won't need to freeze it for as long. Keep the ice cream covered as it is freezing, however; this will prevent ice crystals from forming.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture into another container, if desired.
steps.description: You can leave the ice cream in the loaf pan you froze it in, but you can also scoop it into something that is more convenient, such as a plastic, lidded container. After this, your ice cream is ready to serve.

steps.headline: Purée the frozen banana and peaches until they become smooth.
steps.description: You can do this in a food processor or in a blender. Purée the frozen fruit 15 to 25 seconds at a time, occasionally scrapping the mixture towards the bottom of the food processor/blender with a rubber spatula. Slice and freeze the banana and peaches the night before. You can also use canned frozen peaches, but this may affect the flavor.

steps.headline: Pour in the honey, vanilla extract, and your choice of milk or cream.
steps.description: Here is where you can get really creative. Honey and peaches go great together, but if you are vegan, you may prefer agave nectar or maple syrup. You can also use any type of milk or cream, including: almond milk, coconut milk, cow's milk, half-and-half, or heavy whipping cream.

steps.headline: Blend the mixture again until everything is smooth.
steps.description: From time to time, pause the food processor/blender, and use a rubber spatula to push any lumps or clumps down towards the bottom.

steps.headline: Serve the ice cream, or freeze it for 1 hour.
steps.description: At this point, the ice cream is ready to serve. It will be very soft. If you'd like something firmer, transfer the ice cream into a freezer-safe container, and freeze it for 1 hour.

text: Making Peach Ice Cream Heat the half-and-half, sugar, and salt over medium heat until it reaches 175°F (80°C). Pour the half-and-half into a saucepan, then stir in the sugar and the salt. Heat the mixture over medium heat until the sugar dissolves completely, and the temperature reaches 175°F (80°C). Use a candy thermometer to gauge the temperature. Pour ½ cup (120 milliliters) of the half-and-half mixture into the beaten eggs, and stir. If you have not already done so, crack open and separate the eggs, then beat the yolks with a whisk until they turn light and creamy. Slowly pour ½ cup (120 milliliters) of the half-and-half mixture until the beaten eggs while whisking. This is known as "tempering" the eggs, and prevents them from scrambling. Discard the egg whites, or save them for another recipe. Pour the egg mixture back into the saucepan. Be sure to pour the egg mixture slowly, and to whisk the half-and-half mixture as you pour. This will prevent the eggs from cooking too fast and scrambling. Cook the custard over low heat until it thickens. This will take about 5 minutes. The custard is ready when it has become thick enough to coat the back of a metal spoon and reaches 160°F (72°C). Pour the custard through a strainer into a bowl, and cool it in an ice bath. Fill a sink with ice, then place a bowl inside of it. Set a fine, mesh strainer on top of the bowl, then pour the custard through it. Discard anything caught in the strainer, then stir the custard as it cools. The ice should be level with the custard in the bowl. Do not let any ice get inside of the custard. Make sure that the bowl is large enough to hold the heavy whipping cream as well. You will be mixing everything in this bowl once the mixture cools. Stir in the heavy whipping cream and vanilla extract. Once the custard has cooled, take the bowl out of the ice bath, and stir in the heavy whipping cream and vanilla extract. You can do this using a whisk or rubber spatula. Cover the custard with plastic wrap, and refrigerate it for a few hours. It would be better if you chilled it overnight, however. Be sure to press the plastic wrap right against the surface of the custard. This will prevent a skin from forming on top. Purée the peaches in a blender or food processor. Peel and slice the peaches first, then put them into a blender or food processor. Purée them until you get the consistency you want. The longer you purée them for, the smoother your ice cream will be. If you can't get any fresh peaches, you can use 4 cups (900 grams) of frozen, unsweetened peach slices instead. Let the peaches thaw first; this will make it easier to mix them into the custard. Stir the peach purée into the custard. You can do this using a rubber spatula or a whisk. Keep stirring until the color is even, and there are no streaks or swirls. Freeze the ice cream mixture. Fill your ice cream maker two-thirds of the way with the mixture, then freeze the ice cream according to manufacturer's directions. Keep the rest of the mixture in the fridge while you are freezing your current batch. As you finish freezing each batch, put it into a freezer-safe container, and store it in the fridge. If you don't have an ice cream maker, pour the ice cream mixture into a shallow cake or loaf pan, and freeze it for 45 minutes. Stir the ice cream well, making sure to break up any ice crystals. After that, freeze the ice cream for 2 to 4 hours, stirring it every 30 minutes. Transfer the ice cream into a freezer-safe container, then let it ripen for 2 to 4 hours in the freezer, if desired. Once the ice cream comes out of the ice cream maker, it is ready to serve as a soft-serve type of ice cream. If you want the ice cream to be more firm, you will need to leave it in the freezer for 2 to 4 hours. Even if you are not using an ice cream maker, you might want to do this as well. Keep your ice cream covered as it freezes to prevent ice crystals from forming. Making No-Churn Peach Ice Cream Beat the heavy whipping cream until stiff peaks form. You can do this in an electric stand mixer, a food processor fitted with whisks, or in a bowl with a handheld beater. You want it to feel like whipped cream. Fold in the sweetened condensed milk with a rubber spatula. Pour the condensed milk into the whipped cream slowly while gently folding it with a rubber spatula. You want the color to be even, with no streaks or swirls. Peel, slice, and purée the peaches in a blender or food processor. The longer you purée the peaches, the smoother your ice cream will be. Remember, you can always leave some peach chunks for more texture. Fold the peach purée into the cream mixture. Keep folding the peach purée until the color is even, and no streaks or swirls remain. For a more complex flavor, stir in 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. Pour the mixture into a loaf pan. The larger the pan, the faster your ice cream will freeze. You can always scoop it into a different container later. Cover the mixture with plastic wrap, then freeze it for 6 to 8 hours. The longer you freeze the ice cream for, the harder it will become. If you want more of soft-serve type of ice cream, then you won't need to freeze it for as long. Keep the ice cream covered as it is freezing, however; this will prevent ice crystals from forming. Transfer the mixture into another container, if desired. You can leave the ice cream in the loaf pan you froze it in, but you can also scoop it into something that is more convenient, such as a plastic, lidded container. After this, your ice cream is ready to serve. Making Healthy Peach Ice Cream Purée the frozen banana and peaches until they become smooth. You can do this in a food processor or in a blender. Purée the frozen fruit 15 to 25 seconds at a time, occasionally scrapping the mixture towards the bottom of the food processor/blender with a rubber spatula. Slice and freeze the banana and peaches the night before. You can also use canned frozen peaches, but this may affect the flavor. Pour in the honey, vanilla extract, and your choice of milk or cream. Here is where you can get really creative. Honey and peaches go great together, but if you are vegan, you may prefer agave nectar or maple syrup. You can also use any type of milk or cream, including: almond milk, coconut milk, cow's milk, half-and-half, or heavy whipping cream. Blend the mixture again until everything is smooth. From time to time, pause the food processor/blender, and use a rubber spatula to push any lumps or clumps down towards the bottom. Serve the ice cream, or freeze it for 1 hour. At this point, the ice cream is ready to serve. It will be very soft. If you'd like something firmer, transfer the ice cream into a freezer-safe container, and freeze it for 1 hour.
